items.title: create_query_index() failing on unpartitioned CouchDB database with message invalid_partitioned_option
items.body:
Please [read these guidelines](http://ibm.biz/cdt-issue-guide) before opening an issue.

<!-- Issues will be CLOSED IMMEDIATELY if the following template is not completed. -->

## Bug Description
On trying to create query index in CouchDB 3.0.0, the request fails with an unpartitioned DB with message `HTTPError: 400 Client Error: Bad Request invalid_partitioned_option`
### 1. Steps to reproduce and the simplest code sample possible to demonstrate the issue
<!--
Outline the steps you take to make the problem happen.
Provide the simplest code sample you can, in context, that reproduces the issue.
-->
Execute the following code
```
from cloudant import couchdb
from cloudant.design_document import DesignDocument

with couchdb("admin", "admin", url="http://127.0.0.1:5984") as couchClient:
        _ = couchClient.create_database("foo")
        
with couchdb("admin", "admin", url="http://127.0.0.1:5984") as couchClient:
    db = couchClient["foo"]
    ddoc = DesignDocument(db, document_id="bar")
    ddoc["language"] = "query"
    ddoc.save()

with couchdb("admin", "admin", url="http://127.0.0.1:5984") as couchClient:
    db = couchClient["foo"]
    db.create_query_index(design_document_id="_design/bar",fields=["key"])
```
### 2. What you expected to happen
The index should get created
### 3. What actually happened
Error is thrown with message - `HTTPError: 400 Client Error: Bad Request invalid_partitioned_option Requested partitioned option does not match existing value on design document _design/bar for url: http://127.0.0.1:5984/foo/_index`
## Environment details
<!--
- Version(s) that are affected by this issue.
    > 2.0.2
- Python version
    > 3.6.2
-->
- CouchDB - 3.0.0
- Python 3.7
- python-cloudant - 2.13

## 4. Workaround
In the **cloudant/index.py**, partitioned option was set only for `partitioned = True`. I added an else clause for `partition = False` and that fixed the issue.
Updating line 157-158 of **cloudant/index.py**
```
if self._partitioned:
  payload['partitioned'] = True
else:
  payload['partitioned'] = False
```

items.title: Creating a Design Doc with partitioned = false still creates design doc with partitioned enabled
items.body:
Please [read these guidelines](http://ibm.biz/cdt-issue-guide) before opening an issue.

<!-- Issues will be CLOSED IMMEDIATELY if the following template is not completed. -->

## Bug Description
I created a design document with following params:
ddoc = DesignDocument(db,"doc_id",partitioned=False)
However cloudant still created design doc with partitioned enabled in CouchDB

### 1. Steps to reproduce and the simplest code sample possible to demonstrate the issue
<!--
Outline the steps you take to make the problem happen.
Provide the simplest code sample you can, in context, that reproduces the issue.
-->
Create a design doc with following conf:
ddoc = DesignDocument(db,"doc_id",partitioned=False)
ddoc.add_view(ddoc_name,mapper)
ddoc.save()

### 2. What you expected to happen
The design doc should get created with partition disabled

### 3. What actually happened
The design doc gets created with partition enabled

## Environment details
Cloudant Version: 2.13.0
CouchDB: 3.0.0

## 4. Workaround
I found the possible cause of the issue in src/cloudant/design_document.py
In the init function, the setdefault is given only for partitioned=True. I added the options for else condition as well
if partitioned:
self.setdefault('options', {'partitioned': True})
else:
self.setdefault('options', {'partitioned': False})

it solved my issue.

```
import cloudant

client = cloudant.client.CouchDB(

            connect=True
```

```
import cloudant
client = cloudant.client.CouchDB(
            None,
            None,
            admin_party=False,
            url="http://localhost",
            connect=True

cloudant.database.CloudantDatabase(client name).create(throw_on_exists=False)
```

### 3. What actually happened

It will never launch an exception and will consider the database creation as successful, while the database would never be created.

items.title: Replicator create_target can't be used since you must pass a Database instance
items.body:
## Bug Description

`Replicator` supports creating a replication with `create_target`, but this can't actually be used as `target_db` only supports a database instance which means it must be an existing database.

### 2. What you expected to happen
That `Replicator` supports using `create_target` without pre-creating the database.

### 3. What actually happened
You can only pass it an already created database.

## Environment details
python-cloudant 2.12.0
Python 3.7.4

- Version(s) that are affected by this issue.
    > 2.0.2
- Python version
    > 3.6.2

I've added a print statement for the object that should hold the design document at the program start, and I see that the document shows as having no views (or anything at all) AND the CouchDB log shows NO requests for the design document being made.

items.title: proposal: a faster result iteration
items.body:
Please [read these guidelines](http://ibm.biz/cdt-issue-guide) before opening an issue.

<!-- Issues will be CLOSED IMMEDIATELY if the following template is not completed. -->

## Bug Description

Iterating over a large dataset is sometimes slow. This is not a library disfunction but is related to how couchdb works, ie.

```sh
# take an acceptable time
SKIP=0
time curl -sH 'Content-Type: application/json' \
    http://localhost:5984/db/_design/dd/_view/vv\?limit\=500\&skip\=$SKIP\&group\=true

# this will take ages
SKIP=820000
time curl -sH 'Content-Type: application/json' \
    http://localhost:5984/db/_design/dd/_view/vv\?limit\=500\&skip\=$SKIP\&group\=true

```

So this is inherently true for your library when using current `Result` class logic. 
I've noticed that the different pagination approach [manual propose](https://docs.couchdb.org/en/stable/ddocs/views/pagination.html#paging-alternate-method) does not incur in this slowdown.

I drafted a switch implementation that can allow to iterate based on `startkey` instead of `skip` and you can [see it here](https://github.com/cloudant/python-cloudant/compare/master...aogier:feature/faster-iterator?expand=1), as you see is quite simple and yes is badly coded :grimacing: because is a PoC and I left original implementation under the new alternative.

What do you think? This is maybe somehow related to #389 or not, anyway for me it's a complete game changer that I'd like to have upstream.

Thank you, regards

items.title: wrong unit test test_update_field_success_on_retry
items.body:
## Bug Description

Hi, I'd like to point out that `test_update_field_success_on_retry` uses a wrong mock implementation. In fact in order to invalidate test you could place a [fetch call](https://github.com/cloudant/python-cloudant/compare/master...aogier:feature/test_update_field_success_on_retry?expand=1#diff-5426ff62a320d421a5fdd141988a7eabR538) just before asserts, but the entire linked push should be clear enough if you care to give it a look.  

While I'm still not capable to produce a fix, I could point out that a mock should work with [callables and not called functions](https://github.com/cloudant/python-cloudant/blob/00b6cbb4e297477be214b7202d627bb99bc29223/tests/unit/document_tests.py#L528) so while I'm studying for a fix please be aware of that.

### 1. Steps to reproduce and the simplest code sample possible to demonstrate the issue

Checkout and run [this commit](https://github.com/aogier/python-cloudant/tree/feature/test_update_field_success_on_retry).

### 2. What you expected to happen

Test passing :P

items.title: dict methods (update, clear, pop*) breaks `_id` <-> '_document_id' internal logic
items.body:
## Bug Description

Not overriden dict methods are breaking Document class logic in regards to keep `_id` key in sync with `_document_id` class property. As this breaks my work I'm currently implementing a fix and to me the most sensible way is to completely remove this feature, using `_id` property when needed.  
If I correctly understand the code, this is only used in cloudant.document module and that logic seems completely removable. What do you think? TIA

### 1. Steps to reproduce and the simplest code sample possible to demonstrate the issue

In this example:
```python
import cloudant
from uuid import uuid4

client = cloudant.CouchDB('user', 'pass',
                          url='http://localhost:5984', connect=True)

db = client.create_database('db-' + str(uuid4()))
db.delete()
db.create()


doc = db.create_document({'_id': 'julia006'})
doc['_id'] = 'julia007'
doc.save()
print('_id:')
print('doc:', doc)
print(doc.document_url)

doc = db.create_document({'_id': 'julia008'})
doc.update({'_id': 'julia009'})
doc.save()
print('update:')
print('doc:', doc)
print(doc.document_url)

# db.delete()
```

produce this output:
```
_id:
doc: {'_id': 'julia007', '_rev': '1-967a00dff5e02add41819138abb3284d'}
http://localhost:5984/db-28328934-87a6-4434-ab96-f8cb54351e2d/julia007
update:
doc: {'_id': 'julia009', '_rev': '2-7051cbe5c8faecd085a3fa619e6e6337'}
http://localhost:5984/db-28328934-87a6-4434-ab96-f8cb54351e2d/julia008
```

As you can see, using `__setitem__` correctly produce a new document with an url coherent with `doc._id`. Using `update` instead make a new revision on an `doc._id` mismatching url.

### 2. What you expected to happen

Every dict updating methods (so also `pop`, `popitem`, `clear`, `setdefault`) should work the same way as setitem/delitem dunders.

### 3. What actually happened

Only setitem/delitem keeps ids in sync

items.title: document.Document context manager ignore exceptions
items.body:
## Bug Description

`document.Document` context manager ignores exceptions in inner block, making costly manual housekeeping/rollback necessary in case of errors. Using try/except blocks is indeed feasible but still expensive as I'd have to keep a pristine copy in memory (and I'd get a new `_rev` anyway because `save()` in `__exit__`).

### 1. Steps to reproduce and the simplest code sample possible to demonstrate the issue
```python
import cloudant

client = cloudant.CouchDB('user', 'pass',
                          url='http://localhost:5984', connect=True)
db = client['db']


db.create_document({'_id': 'julia006', 'name': 'julia', 'age': 6})

with cloudant.document.Document(db, 'julia006') as doc:

    doc['age'] = 7
    0 / 0
    doc['prop'] = 'value'

# doc will be partly updated:
# {'_id': 'julia006',
#  '_rev': '2-492dc56da45c97bf6b17ff85e8d83f9d',
#  'name': 'julia', 'age': 7}

```

### 2. What you expected to happen

Document not updated because an error in context manager inner block.

### 3. What actually happened

Document get updated with all the changes made until the error happened.

items.title: cloudant 2.10.1+ requests of large docs slower than requests.get(...).json() or curl
items.body:
## Bug Description

Fetching some large documents from couch takes 20+s when the equivalent with `curl` or python `requests` takes 1s. It's a bug that was introduced in this PR: https://github.com/cloudant/python-cloudant/pull/412.

### 1. Steps to reproduce and the simplest code sample possible to demonstrate the issue

```
pip install cloudant
```

In python shell create a large document with non-ascii characters:
```
from cloudant.client import CouchDB
c = CouchDB('', '', url='http://localhost:5984', admin_party=True, connect=True)
# create large document with non ascii characters
x = c['my_database'].create_document({'_id': 'doc', 'value': u'好'  * 1000000})
```

Now test loading it with different versions of `cloudant` installed:

**2.10.0 is fast**
```
$ pip install cloudant==2.10.0
$ time python -c "from cloudant.client import CouchDB
c = CouchDB('', '', url='http://localhost:5984', admin_party=True, connect=True)
c['my_database']['doc']
"

real	0m0.365s
user	0m0.126s
sys	0m0.090s
```
**2.10.1 is slow**
```
$ pip install cloudant==2.10.1
$ time python -c "from cloudant.client import CouchDB
c = CouchDB('', '', url='http://localhost:5984', admin_party=True, connect=True)
c['my_database']['doc']
"

real	0m30.739s
user	0m29.667s
sys	0m0.314s
```

### 2. What you expected to happen

I expect it to be fast—about as fast as making the request directly with `requests.get(...).json()` or `curl`—and as fast as it is with `cloudant<=2.10.0`.

### 3. What actually happened

It takes 20+s to load, depending on the specific doc.

## Environment details
- Version(s) that are affected by this issue.
    > 2.10.1+
- Python version
    > 2.7

-------------

the cause is this PR: https://github.com/cloudant/python-cloudant/pull/412. The added slowness is concentrated entirely in `resp.text`, which does various things to infer the encoding, some of which are apparently expensive. The solution is to use `json.loads(resp.content.decode('utf-8'))` instead of `json.loads(resp.text)`.

items.title: Document fetch fails when uses its default json decoder and module simplejson is present
items.body:
## Bug Description
`Document.fetch()` fails when it uses its default json decoder and `simplejson` is in the environment. 

### Steps to reproduce and code sample to demonstrate the issue
To reproduce, just run a simple document fetch like this having `simplejson` package in the environment:
```
from cloudant import cloudant
from cloudant.database import CloudantDatabase
from cloudant.document import Document

def fetch_by_id(usr, pwd,url,db_name,id):
  with cloudant(user=usr, passwd=pwd, url=url) as client:
    db = CloudantDatabase(client, db_name)
    doc = Document(db, id)
    if doc.exists():
        doc.fetch()
```

### Expected behavior
The full document should be retrieved by `fetch` function, instead when `simplejson` is reachable in the environment, it will raise the following error:
```
File \"/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/simplejson/__init__.py\", line 535, in loads
return cls(encoding=encoding, **kw).decode(s)
TypeError: __init__() got an unexpected keyword argument 'encoding'
```

### What actually happened
Starting in [this line](https://github.com/cloudant/python-cloudant/blob/2.10.0/src/cloudant/document.py#L170): `self.update(resp.json(cls=self.decoder))`:
1. `json()` function from `requests.models` is called with argument `cls` and value `json.JSONDecoder`, as `self.decoder` [was initialized](https://github.com/cloudant/python-cloudant/blob/2.10.0/src/cloudant/document.py#L69) by default when no decoder is passed to `Document`
2. a JSON decoder [is imported](https://github.com/requests/requests/blob/v2.20.0/requests/models.py#L42) selectively in `requests.compat` module: [when `simplejson` is present](https://github.com/requests/requests/blob/v2.20.0/requests/compat.py#L29), then the json decoder implementation comes from that package
3. the JSON decoder from `simplejson` package is used [to load the contents of the response](https://github.com/requests/requests/blob/v2.20.0/requests/models.py#L888)
4. now, argument `cls` is a `json.JSONDecoder` (see point 1), and it does not expect [an argument called `encoding`](https://github.com/simplejson/simplejson/blob/v3.16.0/simplejson/__init__.py#L535), thus a `TypeError` is raised. 

## Environment details
Version affected: `2.10.0`
Note that in version `2.9.0`, `cls=self.decoder` [was not passed to](https://github.com/cloudant/python-cloudant/commit/82017411beb12717780d036f7308086d8fe37ef5#diff-396eae97315a21001968a65d1ed17e61R171) `resp.json()`.

items.title: Unnecessary requests via cloudant.result.Result iteration
items.body:
## Bug Description

### 1. Steps to reproduce and the simplest code sample possible to demonstrate the issue

Use the couchdb.result.Result class to iterate a view or _all_docs that has more than zero items. Check the logs to notice that there are (at least) two requests.

### 2. What you expected to happen

A single request is issued when the number of rows is less than the page size.

### 3. What actually happened

Two requests are made.

## Environment details

All.

Logic is here:

https://github.com/cloudant/python-cloudant/blob/master/src/cloudant/result.py#L359-L360

There needs to be something like:

```python
if len(result) < self._page_size:
    break
```

Alternatively you can just change the ```if result:``` conditional to something like such:

```python
for row in result:
    yield row
if len(result) < self._page_size:
    break
```

I suppose the same holds for Cloudant._db_updates().

items.title: document.save() does not return response data indicating new _rev
items.body:
## Bug Description

### 1. Steps to reproduce and the simplest code sample possible to demonstrate the issue

This is a request for an extension (backwards compatible).

The `document.save()` method performs a PUT operation on the document. According to the [Cloudant API reference for Documents](https://console.bluemix.net/docs/services/Cloudant/api/document.html#documents), the response to the PUT operation contains data like in the following example:
```
{
    "ok":true,
    "id":"apple",
    "rev":"2-9176459034"
}
```

The important piece of information in that response is the new revision of the updated document. 

Having the new revision at hand significantly simplifies the algorithm to resolve server-side conflicts: The returned new revision can easily be checked against the conflict revisions returned when specifying query parameter `conflicts=true`, to find out whether a successful update lost or won a server-side conflict.

However, the response data is not returned in the current implementation of the `Document.save()` method:

```
    def save(self):
        """
        . . .
        """
        headers = {}
        headers.setdefault('Content-Type', 'application/json')
        if not self.exists():
            self.create()
            return
        put_resp = self.r_session.put(
            self.document_url,
            data=self.json(),
            headers=headers
        )
        put_resp.raise_for_status()
        data = put_resp.json()
        super(Document, self).__setitem__('_rev', data['rev'])
        return   # <-- No response data returned, currently
```

This could easily and backwards compatibly be added by returning the response data as a json object (= dict):

```
    def save(self):
        . . .
        data = put_resp.json()
        super(Document, self).__setitem__('_rev', data['rev'])
        return data    # <-- Response data returned
```

### 2. What you expected to happen

Make the new revision that is already returned in the HTTP response of a document update available to the callers of the `Document.save()` method.

Update the docstring of the method, accordingly.

### 3. What actually happened

`Document.save()` returns `None`, and the returned new revision is not surfaced to the caller.

## Environment details
- Version(s) that are affected by this issue.
    > 2.9.0
- Python version
    > 2.7.14

items.title: document.update_field() raises 409 after successful retry
items.body:
## Bug Description

### 1. Steps to reproduce and the simplest code sample possible to demonstrate the issue

The `Document.update_field()` method raises an HTTPError(409) exception if it succeeds with its retries without exhausting the max retries.

Here is the code in `Document._update_field()` (see [here](https://github.com/cloudant/python-cloudant/blob/master/src/cloudant/document.py#L262)):

```
        # Attempt to save, retrying conflicts up to max_tries.
        try:
            self.save()
        except requests.HTTPError as ex:
            if tries < max_tries and ex.response.status_code == 409:
                self._update_field(
                    action, field, value, max_tries, tries=tries+1)
            raise
```

The `raise` statement should be in an `else:` clause if the previous `if` statement.

If you need a script that reproduces this, let me know, but it is too long to paste here (I think), and from looking at the code, the issue should be obvious.

### 2. What you expected to happen

The `Document.update_field()` method should not raise an HTTPError(409) exception if it ended up with a successful retry without exhausting its max retries. Only if the max retries are exhausted, should it raise the exception.

The description of the `Document.update_field()` method should document that.

There should be test cases that verify that case. :-)

### 3. What actually happened

See above.

## Environment details

- Version(s) that are affected by this issue.
    > 2.9.0
- Python version
    > 2.7.14

items.title: Reads returning old document versions when reusing client
items.body:
I have a serverless function calling a Cloudant database via the [python-cloudant][1] library, with the connection to the client being made outside the function handler so that it is cached, like so:

    httpAdapter = HTTPAdapter(pool_connections=5, pool_maxsize=100)
    client = Cloudant(cloudantUsername, cloudantPassword, url=cloudantURL, adapter=httpAdapter, connect=True)

    def update(event, context):
        db = client['db_name']
        document_id = event['pathParameters']['id']
        document = db[document_id]
        document['foo'] = 'bar'
        document.save()
        return json.dumps(document)

    def get(event, context):
        db = client['db_name']
        document_id = event['pathParameters']['id']
        document = db[document_id]
        return json.dumps(document)

When I do this, I get a very low latency (<100ms) on repeat executions of any kind (create, update, get), because the "connection" is reused, which is the intention. ("connection" in inverted commas since I know cloudant does not have a concept of keeping an open pipe).

If I call `/update` and increment the document `_rev` to `2-XXXX` then call `/get`, the function returns document with `_rev` `2-XXXX` - expected behaviour. 

If I call `/update` again, `_rev` is correctly incremented to `3-XXXX`, but when I call `/get` again, I get document revision `2-XXXX` (i.e. not the updated version). When this is happening, the update function is executing in ~90ms, while the get is executing in ~10ms (too fast to actually be calling the database).

I can eliminate this behaviour by either moving the setup of the Cloudant client inside the function handler like so:

    httpAdapter = HTTPAdapter(pool_connections=5, pool_maxsize=100)

    def update(event, context):
        client = Cloudant(cloudantUsername, cloudantPassword, url=cloudantURL, adapter=httpAdapter, connect=True)
        db = client['db_name']
        document_id = event['pathParameters']['id']
        document = db[document_id]
        document['foo'] = 'bar'
        document.save()
        return json.dumps(document)

    def get(event, context):
        client = Cloudant(cloudantUsername, cloudantPassword, url=cloudantURL, adapter=httpAdapter, connect=True)
        db = client['db_name']
        document_id = event['pathParameters']['id']
        document = db[document_id]
        return json.dumps(document)

or I can explicitly call `document.fetch()` in the get handler:

    def get(event, context):
        db = client['db_name']
        document_id = event['pathParameters']['id']
        document = db[document_id]
        document.fetch()
        return json.dumps(document)

In either case, `/get` always returns the correct revision of the document.

Getting an old version of the document is unexpected since I believed putting the client setup outside the handler would only cache the client between executions, but calls to the database would still be made each time the handler is called. It looks like they are being made when `/update` is called, presumably since `document.save()` forces it, but not when `/get` is called without a forced call with `.fetch()`.

Is putting the client declaration outside the handler somehow caching the database? If so, is there any way to prevent it from doing so? Are context managers required in this scenario?

  [1]: https://github.com/cloudant/python-cloudant

            doc.put_attachment(attachment = "encode.bin",data = kwargs['encoded'], content_type = 'application/octet-stream')

        return doc

items.title: sort changed sort_field for get_search_result()
items.body:
In the new version of the Cloudant, the `sort`  parameter has been changed to `sort_field` for searching using design documents. Therefore, this needs to be updated in `_common_util.py` file accordingly, so that function `get_search_result()` is able to return the results properly.

Current function call:
`
results = get_search_result(designDoc, indexName, sort = "myfield<number>")
`

Modification required as per new change:

`
results = get_search_result(designDoc, indexName, sort_field = "myfield<number>")
`

It appears that the Document context handler does not behave as described in the documentation.  According to [the docs](http://python-cloudant.readthedocs.io/en/latest/document.html), the document ID is optional to specify (allowing the database to set the _id itself.) from cloudant.document import Document
```
from cloudant.client import Cloudant

db = client['testdb']
with Document(db) as doc:
```

items.title: Incorrect result when accessing views with complex keys
items.body:
- Cloudant (python-cloudant) version(s) that are affected by this issue: 2.7.0
- Python version: 2.7 and 3.5

## Cloudant Python library use:
```
client = Cloudant(user, password, url=url, connect=True)
db = client[dbname]
stock_doc = DesignDocument(db, document_id='stocks')
stock_doc.fetch()
category_view = stockdoc.get_view('bycategory')
rslt = category_view.result
print(rslt[["Real Estate Investment Trusts",None,None,None,None]: ["Real Estate Investment Trusts",{},{},{},{}]) 
```

### Output is incorrect:
```
[{u'value': 1, u'key': None}]
```

### JSON doc example:
```
{
  "_id": "stock-DLR",
  "_rev": "1-c1ce76fde124d364efc0220170b68314",
  "type": "stock",
  "symbol": "DLR",
  "buybelow": 100,
  "name": "Digital Realty Trust",
  "category": "Real Estate Investment Trusts",
  "active": true,
  "comments": "Low-risk play on explosive growth of cloud computing, at home and abroad",
  "updated": "2018-02-10"
}
```

### design doc view function:
```
function (doc) {
  if (doc.type === 'stock') {
    emit([doc.category,doc.symbol,doc.name,doc.buybelow,doc.comments], 1);
  }
}
```

## Now using requests library for same function:
```
db = 'investfolio-bradbonn'
view_url = "{0}/{1}/_design/{2}/_view/{3}".format(
    url,
    db,
    'stocks',
    'bycategory'
)
view_parameters = {
    "startkey": '["{0}",{1},{2},{3},{4}]'.format("Real Estate Investment Trusts",'null','null','null','null'),
    "endkey": '["{0}",{1},{2},{3},{4}]'.format("Real Estate Investment Trusts",'{}','{}','{}','{}'),
    "reduce": 'false'
}
r = requests.get(
    view_url,
    auth = (user,password),
    headers = my_header,
    params = view_parameters
)
jsondata = r.json()
pprint.pprint(jsondata)
```

### Output is correct:
```
{u'offset': 0,
 u'rows': [{u'id': u'dd1687ac1ca0d2f10be71665aa3f2761',
            u'key': [u'Real Estate Investment Trusts',
                     u'DLR',
                     u'Digital Realty Trust',
                     100,
                     u'Low-risk play on explosive growth of cloud computing, at home and abroad'],
            u'value': 1}],
 u'total_rows': 1}
```

items.title: Support IAM authentication in replication documents.
items.body:
_Parent Issue: https://github.com/cloudant/cloudant-sync/issues/31_

Currently `db.creds['basic_auth']` returns `None` when using an IAM client . As a result, all replication documents created using IAM clients _don't_ contain source/target database credentials.

_Work Required:_
* Expose the IAM key via the client session ([here](https://github.com/cloudant/python-cloudant/blob/2.7.0/src/cloudant/_client_session.py#L194)).
* Rework the [Replicator](https://github.com/cloudant/python-cloudant/blob/2.7.0/src/cloudant/replicator.py#L77-L93) class to correctly inject the IAM key into the replication document (when databases are backed by an IAM client).
* Enable replicator tests for IAM clients (currently disabled).
* Add more unit tests as appropriate.

items.title: Remove src/trg optional parameters in replicator API

items.body:
Consider the following snippet (where `id=u'37c1d704a01a462c8a77d9d4e53d4b11'` and doc is retrieved from the database):
```
    logging.debug(id in self.db)
    logging.debug(doc)
```

It yields:
```
DEBUG: 2017-08-08 22:29:03,344 {couchdb_live_test.py:26}: False 
DEBUG: 2017-08-08 22:29:03,344 {couchdb_live_test.py:27}: {u'base_data': u'image', u'portion_class': u'book', u'path': u'english', u'_id': u'37c1d704a01a462c8a77d9d4e53d4b11', u'jsonClass': u'BookPortion'}
```

items.title: deleting within a context manager does not persist..
items.body:
With a couchdb database db, when I do:
```
    from cloudant.document import Document
    with Document(db, doc_id) as db_doc:
      db_doc.delete()
      logging.debug(db[doc_id].exists())
    logging.debug(db[doc_id].exists())
```
the first `logging.debug(db[doc_id].exists())` prints False, while the second prints True. This is rather strange, and points to a bug either in the context manager or the delete documentation.

```python
cloudant_session = Cloudant.bluemix(os.getenv('VCAP_SERVICES'), 'instance-name')
```

items.title: Using cloudant_bluemix function throws an exception
items.body:
The current `cloudant_bluemix` function doesn't appear to work. It throws an exception because it uses incorrect syntax to create the Cloudant class. 

**Using:**

- cloudant==2.5.0
- Python 2.7.12
- Python 3.6.2

**Steps to reproduce**

The following code illustrates the problem given the `VCAP_SERVICES` environment variable has been set by Bluemix (or manually):
```
import os
from cloudant import cloudant_bluemix
with cloudant_bluemix(os.getenv('VCAP_SERVICES')) as client: 
    print(client.all_dbs())
```

**Expected results**  

A list of databases from your CloudantNoSQL service in Bluemix. e.g.:
```
[u'images', u'items', u'orders', u'status']
```

**Observed results in Python 2.7.12**

When executing the code in Python 2.7.12 the following exception occurs:
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "test.py", line 3, in <module>
    with cloudant_bluemix(os.getenv('VCAP_SERVICES')) as client: 
  File "/usr/local/Cellar/python/2.7.13_1/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/lib/python2.7/contextlib.py", line 17, in __enter__
    return self.gen.next()
  File "/Users/rofrano/bx-test/venv/lib/python2.7/site-packages/cloudant/__init__.py", line 128, in cloudant_bluemix
    **kwargs
TypeError: __init__() takes exactly 3 arguments (1 given)
```
**Observed results in Python 3.6.2**

When executing the code in Python 3.6.2 the following exception occurs:
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "test.py", line 3, in <module>
    with cloudant_bluemix(os.getenv('VCAP_SERVICES')) as client: 
  File "/usr/local/Cellar/python3/3.6.2/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.6/lib/python3.6/contextlib.py", line 81, in __enter__
    return next(self.gen)
  File "/Users/rofrano/github/bx-test/venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/cloudant/__init__.py", line 128, in cloudant_bluemix
    **kwargs
TypeError: __init__() missing 2 required positional arguments: 'cloudant_user' and 'auth_token'
```
**Offending code on line 128**

Line 128 of `./cloudant/__init__.py` passes all parameters as **kwargs when the first two parameters should be passed as args:
```
    cloudant_session = Cloudant(
        username=service.username,
        password=service.password,
        url=service.url,
        **kwargs
    )
```

**Correct code**

This version of line 128 in `./cloudant/__init__.py` fixes the problem:
```
    cloudant_session = Cloudant(
        service.username,
        service.password,
        **dict(kwargs, url=service.url)
    )
```
It seems to be working fine for me with this change. I can fix it and send a pull request if you want (up to you).

items.title: Custom JSON encoder not specified in `set_revision_limit`
items.body:
The custom JSON encoder is incorrectly specified here https://github.com/cloudant/python-cloudant/blob/master/src/cloudant/database.py#L761.

Note, as of Python 3.6 the `json.dump` optional parameters are keyword-only. In earlier versions the additional argument is silently ignored.

_From the docs..._
>To use a custom JSONEncoder subclass (e.g. one that overrides the default() method to serialize additional types), specify it with the cls kwarg; otherwise JSONEncoder is used.

items.title: Support Python 3.6
Remove redundant exists() check for client create_database call
items.body:
When using the client `create_database` method to create a database you are effectively making a call to the database `exists` method twice.  Once [here}(https://github.com/cloudant/python-cloudant/blob/master/src/cloudant/client.py#L227) in `create_database` and then one more time [here](https://github.com/cloudant/python-cloudant/blob/master/src/cloudant/database.py#L340) in the database `create` method.

I propose that we fix this logic and remove the redundant call to `exists` by adding a keyword argument to the `create` method in CouchDatabase that would allow for turning on/off the "exists" check [here](https://github.com/cloudant/python-cloudant/blob/master/src/cloudant/database.py#L340).  The default would be for the check to be "on" so that no current behavior is affected.

I then propose fixing the logic [here](https://github.com/cloudant/python-cloudant/blob/master/src/cloudant/client.py#L226-L232) to utilize this new switch to turn off the redundant exists check in the `create_database` method of the CouchDB client class.

items.title: Improve CloudantException design
items.body:
Using the ResultException class as a guide, we can improve the error handling design by 1) have specific class exceptions for many or all of the modules (i.e. `CloudantClientException` and 2) move the error messages from `error.py` and the other modules to an internal `messages.py` module to reduce clutter.

After a discussion with @alfinkel, will follow these guidelines:
(1) try and preserve Python `dict` behavior
(2) only throwing Cloudant exceptions when trying to communicate errors encountered pre-remote database interaction

items.title: Specify a default timeout that isn't forever
items.body:
The [Requests library does not have a timeout set by default](http://docs.python-requests.org/en/master/user/advanced/#timeouts). To prevent python-cloudant waiting forever for a HTTP connection or a response we should set a reasonable default timeout on all requests and allow customization.

- Cloudant (python-cloudant) version(s) that are affected by this issue.
    - All 2.x
- Python version
    - Any

items.title: Implement method to create Cloudant client from VCAP services environment variable
Support new view parameters
items.body:
CouchDB 2.1.0 will include new view options to replace the existing `stale` parameter. These new parameters are shown in the table below with their mappings to the old API.


|# |	New API |      Old API   | Observed Behaviour (q=8,n=3)|
|--|----------|------------|--------------------------------|
|1|stable=true&update=true|Didn't exist|Blocks; Only 8 ushard indexers started|
|2|stable=true&update=false|stale=ok|Non-blocking; no indexers started; Matches previous API
|3|stable=true&update=lazy|stale=update_after|Non-blocking; 24 indexers started; Matches previous API|
|4|stable=false&update=true|stale not defined|Blocks; 24 indexers started; Matches previous API
|5|stable=false&update=false|Didn't exist|Non-blocking; no indexers started
|6|stable=false&update=lazy|Didn't exist|Non-blocking; 8 indexers started, all same node
------------

See [COUCHDB-3227](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/COUCHDB-3227)

items.title: Stack overflow iterating over InfiniteFeed
items.body:
Noticed in a log file that iterating over an `InfiniteFeed` object when calling the database method `infinite_changes(...)` had caused a stack overflow, small snippet from the stack trace:

```
…snip...
  File "/opt/sapi/manifold/venv/lib/python2.7/site-packages/cloudant/feed.py", line 259, in next
    return super(InfiniteFeed, self).next()
  File "/opt/sapi/manifold/venv/lib/python2.7/site-packages/cloudant/feed.py", line 164, in next
    return self.next()
  File "/opt/sapi/manifold/venv/lib/python2.7/site-packages/cloudant/feed.py", line 259, in next
    return super(InfiniteFeed, self).next()
  File "/opt/sapi/manifold/venv/lib/python2.7/site-packages/cloudant/feed.py", line 164, in next
…snip...
```
Appears that due to the `next` function being recursive on a skipped line (i.e. heartbeat, etc...) having several hundred skips in a row will blow the stack. This also can create a messy stack trace if there are a number of skips and an error.

Replacing the recursive call with a loop should resolve the problem, I'll follow this up with a patch.

items.title: Improve pylint reporting
repl_id not correctly handled between Replicator and create_document
items.body:
python-cloudant 2.2.0
Python 2.7.11

When replicator.Replicator creates a replication that isn't passed a repl_id parameter it creates one of type uuid.uuid4() which is wrapped in a call to unicode_ from _2.to3.  The unicode_ function effectively does nothing to the generated ID because it doesn't have a decode method and it passes it back unchanged.  When create_replication tries to create the document it fails because the UUID object isn't a string and doesn't have a startswith() method.  Somewhere we would need to cast the UUID object as a string and indeed it is done in the tests with "{}".format()

```
from cloudant import cloudant
from cloudant.replicator import Replicator

with cloudant(USERNAME, PASSWORD, account=ACCOUNT) as client:
    clone = Replicator(client)
    master_db = client['master']
    target_db = client['repl_target']
    clone.create_replication(master_db, target_db)
```

  File "<stdin>", line 5, in <module>
  File "C:\Users\bagadd01\.virtualenvs\PDR\lib\site-packages\cloudant\replicator.py", line 108, in create_replication
    return self.database.create_document(data, throw_on_exists=True)
  File "C:\Users\bagadd01\.virtualenvs\PDR\lib\site-packages\cloudant\database.py", line 155, in create_document
    if docid and docid.startswith('_design/'):
AttributeError: 'UUID' object has no attribute 'startswith'

items.title: Clean up append_response_error_content function
items.body:
The` _common_util.append_response_error_content` function currently has an unused `**kwargs` argument as part of the function signature and a `#pylint: disable=unused-argument` comment to force pylint to ignore this.  In this case, pylint is correct in flagging `**kwargs` as unused and it should be removed along with the pylint "disable" comment.  Also the function could stand to be cleaned up and rewritten.  Suggest this:

```python
def append_response_error_content(response):
    resp_dict = response.json()
    if response.status_code >= 400 and resp_dict is not None:
        reason = resp_dict.get('reason', '')
        error = resp_dict.get('error', '')
        response.reason = '{0} {1}'.format(error, reason)
    return response
```

```
cloudant.error.CloudantArgumentError: Argument startkey not instance of expected type: (<type 'int'>, <type 'basestring'>, <class '_abcoll.Sequence'>)
```

Adding `long` type for validating startkey, endkey, and other arguments will fix this issue.

items.title: Automatically handle session renewal
items.body: Currently a user needs to handle the starting of a new session when theirs expires by either creating a new client, or calling `client.session_login`. What we should do is handle this situation transparently to user and renew the session if we receive a response indicating the session has expired. And retry the user request and return the results.

items.title: Couchdb 2.0 support
items.body: Are there any plans of including couchdb 2.0 support.

items.title: Add all() convenience method
items.body:
Retrieving the entire set of data from a `Result` object is awkward when using result slices.  To retrieve the full data set for a `Result` using a slice, you must do something like:

``` python
result = Result(...)
data = result[:]
```

...which is a bit awkward.  We should add an `all()` method call that performs the same functionality as `result[:]` so that we could do something like:

``` python
result = Result(...)
data = result.all()
```

items.title: Add auto connect kwarg to client constructor
items.body: Add an auto connect keyword argument to the client `__init__`.  When set, the client will perform the `connect` logic as part of object instantiation.

items.title: Misleading docstring in UnitTestDbBase.setupClass
items.body: Again, I was poking around in the code and found this [note](https://github.com/cloudant/python-cloudant/blob/master/tests/unit/unit_t_db_base.py#L80-L82) that says that Admin Party is unsupported, which is no longer true.  I think the entire note should be removed since Admin Party is now supported by the library so that future maintainers of the code will not be confused.  I'm categorizing this as "testing" since I think it is neither a bug or a documentation issue.

items.title: ADMIN_PARTY environment setting is not needed in JenkinsFile
items.body: I was poking around in the repo and stumbled upon the recently added JenkinsFile.  It looks like the `ADMIN_PARTY` environment variable is being set to `true` [here](https://github.com/cloudant/python-cloudant/blob/master/Jenkinsfile#L13) which is unnecessary for Cloudant tests and only applies to running tests against CouchDB.  This does not cause any problem right now given the way the tests are written but if things change then this could become an issue in the future.  I would suggest to remove this line of code from the JenkinsFile since it currently does nothing and may possibly do some harm later on.

items.title: "q" is not a valid option for _search query
items.body:
In python-cloudant 2.1.1 for both Python 2 and 3 "q" needs to be a valid parameter for calls to the database `get_search_result` method.  Initial work was done in PR #210 but apparently this bug slipped through and "q" is still not actually acknowledged as a valid parameter.  The problem is that when the parameter validation performed [here](https://github.com/cloudant/python-cloudant/blob/master/src/cloudant/database.py#L1343) checks against the `SEARCH_INDEX_ARGS` defined [here](https://github.com/cloudant/python-cloudant/blob/master/src/cloudant/_common_util.py#L117-L136), "q" is not included in that dictionary of valid arguments.  The bug slipped through because the test [here](https://github.com/cloudant/python-cloudant/blob/master/tests/unit/database_tests.py#L1377) is incorrectly using "query" where it should be using "q".  Changing to "q" would reveal the bug.

So the course of action here is to add "q" to the SEARCH_INDEX_ARGS and fix the test to use "q" instead of "query".

items.title: test_get_search_result_with_both_q_and_query failure
items.body:
The test `tests.unit.database_tests.CloudantDatabaseTests.test_get_search_result_with_both_q_and_query` failed with this message:

```
Error Message
"A si[15 chars]rameter is required. Found: {'query': 'julia*', 'q': 'julia*'}" != "A si[15 chars]rameter is required. Found: {'q': 'julia*', 'query': 'julia*'}"
- A single query/q parameter is required. Found: {'query': 'julia*', 'q': 'julia*'}
?                                                   ----
+ A single query/q parameter is required. Found: {'q': 'julia*', 'query': 'julia*'}
```

The problem is that the test asserts a static message against a generated message wrt the query parameters, so the ordering is not guaranteed. We should either just assert the beginning of the message or make sure the parameters are compared or issued in the same order.
- Cloudant (python-cloudant) version(s) that are affected by this issue.
  - master
- Python version 
  - 3.5.2
- A small code sample that demonstrates the issue.
  - `tests.unit.database_tests.CloudantDatabaseTests.test_get_search_result_with_both_q_and_query`

items.title: json.dumps not consistently setting cls kwarg to supplied encoder
items.body:
All versions of python-cloudant and Python are affected.

We specifically allow for setting an `encoder` via key word argument when constructing a `client` instance.  The assumption is that this encoder would be set for all JSON encoding handled by the library, in other words all instances of `json.dumps` in the code should have a `cls` setting pointing to the encoder set on the client.  However, the use of the `encoder` is being used in some instances and not others.

We should fix this and update all occurrences of `json.dumps` to have the `cls` keyword argument set to the client encoder.
